Partial Dependence Plot

Source: R/partial_dep.R
partial_dep.Rd

Estimates the partial dependence function of feature(s) v over a grid of values. Both multivariate and multivariable situations are supported. By default, the resulting values are plotted.

partial_dep(object, ...)

# S3 method for default
partial_dep(
  object,
  v,
  X,
  pred_fun = stats::predict,
  BY = NULL,
  by_size = 5L,
  grid = NULL,
  grid_size = 49L,
  trim = c(0.01, 0.99),
  strategy = c("uniform", "quantile"),
  n_max = 1000L,
  w = NULL,
  ...
)

# S3 method for ranger
partial_dep(
  object,
  v,
  X,
  pred_fun = function(m, X, ...) stats::predict(m, X, ...)$predictions,
  BY = NULL,
  by_size = 5L,
  grid = NULL,
  grid_size = 49L,
  trim = c(0.01, 0.99),
  strategy = c("uniform", "quantile"),
  n_max = 1000L,
  w = NULL,
  ...
)

# S3 method for Learner
partial_dep(
  object,
  v,
  X,
  pred_fun = function(m, X) m$predict_newdata(X)$response,
  BY = NULL,
  by_size = 5L,
  grid = NULL,
  grid_size = 49L,
  trim = c(0.01, 0.99),
  strategy = c("uniform", "quantile"),
  n_max = 1000L,
  w = NULL,
  ...
)

Arguments

object

Fitted model object.

...

Additional arguments passed to pred_fun(object, X, ...), for instance type = "response" in a glm() model.

v

Vector of feature names.

X

A data.frame or matrix serving as background dataset.

pred_fun

Prediction function of the form function(object, X, ...), providing K >= 1 numeric predictions per row. Its first argument represents the model object, its second argument a data structure like X. Additional arguments (such as type = "response" in a GLM) can be passed via .... The default, stats::predict(), will work in most cases. Note that column names in a resulting matrix of predictions will be used as default column names in the results.

BY

Optional grouping vector or a column name. The partial dependence function is calculated per BY group. Each BY group uses the same evaluation grid to improve assessment of (non-)additivity. Numeric BY variables with more than by_size disjoint values will be binned into by_size quantile groups of similar size. Subsampling of X is done within group.

by_size

Numeric BY variables with more than by_size unique values will be binned into quantile groups. Only relevant if BY is not NULL.

grid

A vector (if length(v) == 1L), or a matrix/data.frame otherwise. If NULL, calculated via multivariate_grid().

grid_size

Controls the approximate grid size. If x has p columns, then each (non-discrete) column will be reduced to about the p-th root of grid_size values.

trim

A non-discrete numeric variable is trimmed at these quantile probabilities before calculations. Set to c(0, 1) for no trimming.

strategy

How to find evaluation points of non-discrete numeric columns? Either "uniform" (via pretty()) or "quantile", see description of univariate_grid().

n_max

If X has more than n_max rows, a random sample of n_max rows is selected from X. In this case, set a random seed for reproducibility.

w

Optional vector of case weights for each row of X.

Value

An object of class "partial_dep" containing these elements:

  • pd: data.frame containing the partial dependencies.

  • v: Same as input v.

  • K: Number of columns of prediction matrix.

  • pred_names: Column names of prediction matrix.

  • BY: Column name of grouping variable (or NULL).

Methods (by class)

  • partial_dep(default): Default method.

  • partial_dep(ranger): Method for "ranger" models.

  • partial_dep(Learner): Method for "mlr3" models.

Partial Dependence Functions

Let \(F: R^p \to R\) denote the prediction function that maps the \(p\)-dimensional feature vector \(\mathbf{x} = (x_1, \dots, x_p)\) to its prediction. Furthermore, let $$ F_s(\mathbf{x}_s) = E_{\mathbf{x}_{\setminus s}}(F(\mathbf{x}_s, \mathbf{x}_{\setminus s})) $$ be the partial dependence function of \(F\) on the feature subset \(\mathbf{x}_s\), where \(s \subseteq \{1, \dots, p\}\), as introduced in Friedman (2001). Here, the expectation runs over the joint marginal distribution of features \(\mathbf{x}_{\setminus s}\) not in \(\mathbf{x}_s\).

Given data, \(F_s(\mathbf{x}_s)\) can be estimated by the empirical partial dependence function

$$ \hat F_s(\mathbf{x}_s) = \frac{1}{n} \sum_{i = 1}^n F(\mathbf{x}_s, \mathbf{x}_{i\setminus s}), $$ where \(\mathbf{x}_{i\setminus s}\) \(i = 1, \dots, n\), are the observed values of \(\mathbf{x}_{\setminus s}\).

A partial dependence plot (PDP) plots the values of \(\hat F_s(\mathbf{x}_s)\) over a grid of evaluation points \(\mathbf{x}_s\).

References

Friedman, Jerome H. "Greedy Function Approximation: A Gradient Boosting Machine." Annals of Statistics 29, no. 5 (2001): 1189-1232.

Examples

# MODEL 1: Linear regression
fit <- lm(Sepal.Length ~ . + Species * Petal.Length, data = iris)
(pd <- partial_dep(fit, v = "Species", X = iris))
#> Partial dependence object (3 rows). 
#>       Extract via $pd. Top rows:
#> 
#>      Species        y
#> 1     setosa 5.476540
#> 2 versicolor 5.748857
#> 3  virginica 5.207491
plot(pd)


# Stratified by numeric BY variable (which is automatically binned)
pd <- partial_dep(fit, v = "Species", X = iris, BY = "Petal.Length")
plot(pd)


# Multivariable input
v <- c("Species", "Petal.Width")
pd <- partial_dep(fit, v = v, X = iris, grid_size = 100L)
plot(pd, rotate_x = TRUE)


# With grouping
pd <- partial_dep(fit, v = v, X = iris, grid_size = 100L, BY = "Petal.Length")
plot(pd, rotate_x = TRUE)


# MODEL 2: Multi-response linear regression
fit <- lm(as.matrix(iris[1:2]) ~ Petal.Length + Petal.Width * Species, data = iris)
plot(partial_dep(fit, v = "Petal.Width", X = iris, BY = iris$Species))

plot(partial_dep(fit, v = c("Species", "Petal.Width"), X = iris), rotate_x = TRUE)


# Multivariate, multivariable, and BY (no plot available)
pd <- partial_dep(fit, v = c("Petal.Width", "Petal.Length"), X = iris, BY = "Species")
pd
#> Partial dependence object (126 rows). 
#>       Extract via $pd. Top rows:
#> 
#>   Species Petal.Width Petal.Length Sepal.Length Sepal.Width
#> 1  setosa         0.0            1     4.469355    3.177012
#> 2  setosa         0.5            1     4.677664    3.558038
#> 3  setosa         1.0            1     4.885973    3.939064

# MODEL 3: Gamma GLM -> pass options to predict() via ...
fit <- glm(
  Sepal.Length ~ . + Petal.Width:Species, 
  data = iris, 
  family = Gamma(link = log)
)
plot(partial_dep(fit, v = "Species", X = iris, type = "response"))
